key_insight: What looks like a reasoning failure on abstract benchmarks (ARC, ARC-AGI) is largely a perception failure — a "perception bottleneck". When perceptual input is cleaned or replaced by symbolic representations, model reasoning performance improves substantially.
problem_solved: Reveals that standard abstract-reasoning benchmarks conflate perceptual decoding and high-level reasoning, causing misattribution of failures to reasoning when they often stem from perception; provides a methodology to disentangle and properly evaluate the two.
method: Systematic error analysis of state-of-the-art vision–language models on ARC/ARC-AGI to classify failures as perceptual vs reasoning.
Controlled experiments that supply models with ground-truth or cleaned symbolic encodings (bypassing perception) and compare results to raw-image inputs.
Propose diagnostic evaluation protocols / dataset splits that isolate perceptual difficulty from core reasoning tasks so progress can be measured more precisely.
impact: For researchers and practitioners, this reframes where effort should be invested — improving perception/representation and designing disentangled benchmarks yields more meaningful measures of reasoning progress. It guides architecture and evaluation choices so that claimed reasoning advances are not artifacts of easier perception.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing: Image → Perception (segmentation/encoding) → Symbolic representation → Reasoning, with the 'Perception Bottleneck' highlighted.
Bar chart comparing model performance on raw images vs. ground-truth symbolic inputs to illustrate the gap attributable to perception.
Side-by-side example ARC tasks: original input, common perceptual failure (e.g., mis-segmentation), and correct symbolic encoding/solution.
Schematic of the proposed diagnostic evaluation split (icons for 'perception test' and 'reasoning test') and recommended workflow for model assessment.
paper_title: Your Reasoning Benchmark May Not Test Reasoning: Revealing Perception Bottleneck in Abstract Reasoning Benchmarks
paper_authors: Xinhe Wang, Jin Huang, Xingjian Zhang, Tianhao Wang, Jiaqi W. Ma
